result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt:
9:15 AM Prosecuting attorney David R. Knaapen appeared in court for the State of Wisconsin, Defendant Zachariah F Mews appeared in court. Court questions defendant regarding non-representation. Court will proceed with the option of having the matter reheard.  

Officer Derek Iverson is sworn and questioned by Attorney Knaapen.  Testifies that on March 5 he was dispatched to an alley regarding a disturbance.  Witness identifies the defendant in the courtroom.  Testifies that the defendant expelled bodily fluids at him. 

Court finds probable cause to believe that a felony was committed and that the defendant committed it. Bond is continued.
Arraignment scheduled for April 4, 2022 at 10:00 am.

No controlled substances without a valid prescription. Absolute sobriety. Do not enter any establishment whose primary purpose is to sell or serve alcohol. No violent or abusive contact w/victim - MBS $2500
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment on March 15, 2022 at 09:15 am.

No controlled substances without a valid prescription.  Absolute sobriety  Do not enter any establishment whose primary purpose is to sell or serve alcohol.  No violent or abusive contact w/victim - MBS.
01:45 PM Defendant Zachariah F Mews in court, in custody.  Daniel McGrath appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Zachariah F Mews appeared by video means.
